title: CAMS 51
text: The CAMS 51 was a transport <a href="flying%20boat">flying boat</a> built in France in the mid-1920s. Designed as a private venture by <a href="Chantiers%20A%C3%A9ro-Maritimes%20de%20la%20Seine">Chantiers Aéro-Maritimes de la Seine</a> (CAMS), it was a conventional <a href="biplane">biplane</a> with two <a href="radial%20engine">radial engine</a>s mounted in a tractor-pusher installation in the interplane gap. One example (the 51C) was sold to <a href="A%C3%A9ropostale%20%28aviation%29">Aéropostale</a>, which used it for tests in preparation for <a href="Transatlantic%20flight">transatlantic</a> services. CAMS also built a militarised version as the 51R3 in the hopes of interesting the <a href="French%20Navy">French Navy</a> in it as a <a href="reconnaissance%20aircraft">reconnaissance aircraft</a>, but no order was forthcoming. A final aircraft was built as a record-breaking machine originally designated 51-3 R that broke the world payload-to-altitude record on 18 August <a href="1927%20in%20aviation">1927</a> by lifting 2,000 kg to 4,684 m (15,368 ft). This aircraft was later used as a pathfinder for French airmail routes to South America.
